newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: CSR says aluminium profits seen falling.
newsitem.headline: CSR says aluminium profits seen falling.

text.p: CSR Ltd said on Monday profits from its aluminium and alumina divisions for 1997/98 (April/March) would be below those for 1996/97.
"We expect profit to be slightly below last year based on current prices and exchange rates," chairman Alan Coates told the company's annual general meeting.
Coates said profits from the division would be lower despite operating at the low end of the industry cost curve for world producers.
Aluminium and alumina are priced in U.S. dollars in international markets.
Analysts expect demand for alumina and aluminium to taper off during the second half of calendar 1997, leading to a build-up in supply.
CSR owns a 25.2 percent stake in the Tomago aluminium smelter in New South Wales.
CSR's stake in the smelter, Australia's largest, is owned through its 70 percent interest in Gove Aluminium Ltd, which holds a 36.05 percent share of the smeelter.
The other owners are France's Pechiney SA 36.05 percent, Germany's VAW Aluminium AG with 12.4 percent and life insurer Australian Mutual Provident Society (AMP) with 15.5 percent.
CSR also holds a 21 percent interest in the Gove alumina refinery in the Northern Territory.
Overall, sales from CSR's aluminium division fell five percent to A$396 million in its 1996/97 year ended March 31.
Production capacity at the smelter currently is being expanded by 40,000 tonnes to 440,000 tonnes a year.

CSR said overall profits for the current year should improve over the previous year, owing in part to contributions from its building, construction and timber businesses as the housing industry recovered.
